The Fed's long history of tensions with presidents
subhead: Since returning to the White House, Donald Trump has targeted the independence of the Federal Reserve. The institution has been at the heart of constant tension between the need for a strong monetary authority and the wishes of successive presidents, who have demanded that it fund the economy at low cost.

title: Charlie Kirk assassination: Suspect Tyler Robinson charged with aggravated murder
subhead: The prosecutor announced that he would seek the death penalty, 'based solely on the available evidence and circumstances and nature of the crime.' The 22-year-old defendant had confessed his actions to people close to him before turning himself in.
byline: By Arnaud Leparmentier (San Francisco (United States) correspondent)

title: A cappuccino war breaks out in Berlin
subhead: In the German capital, a coffee chain is booming on the promise of affordable prices. The success is generating as much enthusiasm as hostility, with some seeing it as the work of destructive 'turbo-capitalism.'

title: The singular Georges de La Tour at the Musée Jacquemart-André
subhead: Some 30 works attributed to the French painter, whose life remains little known, are on display in Paris. In the absence of a clear chronology, the paintings have been categorized by subject − both secular and sacred.

title: Le Pen's RN says it wants power, but acts like it fears it
subhead: Marine Le Pen and Jordan Bardella's statements about whether they would seek to govern after new snap elections raise questions about their true willingness to wield power before the 2027 presidential election.

title: Robert Redford, legend of American cinema, dies at 89
subhead: From 'The Sting' to 'Out of Africa,' the actor and director embodied a certain kind of American cinema, generous and progressive. To encourage independent production, he created the Sundance Institute in 1981. He died on Tuesday, at the age of 89.

title: Qatar owns 20% of property on Paris' Champs-Elysées
subhead: By reviewing land registry records, Le Monde determined that one-fifth of the facades on Paris's prestigious avenue are owned by the small Gulf monarchy.
byline: By Véronique Chocron and Manon Romain
